title: Colony in Space
dialogue_triumphs: The Master: 'It's always innocent bystanders who suffer.'
dialogue_disasters: There's no animal life, just a few birds and insects.
goofs: In episode two the monitor screen on board their ship turns bright blue in every close-up.
The Brigadier is fortunate that when he walks to where the TARDIS vanished and tells it to 'come back at once', that it does so in a different corner of the room.
Jo's scepticism about the TARDIS being mobile is odd as she saw it dematerialize in the last story.
If the Master was so ready to kill the Doctor at the end of episode four, why does he use a non-lethal gas when the Doctor goes into his TARDIS?

future_history: Earth is home to 100 billion people, polluted, with a repressive government. Humans are prone to epidemics, some housed in floating island blocks. Planets are assigned for colonisation or mining. Disputes are resolved by the Adjudicators Bureau. Robbing spaceships is a capital offence under interplanetary law.
additional_notes: The episode features fashion victims like Jo's big belt, the colonists' hippy gear, and Dent's hairdo. The Exariens once used the Doomsday Weapon to destroy a star, forming the Crab Nebula.
bottom_line: Well-meaning, and much more interesting before the Master arrives, at which point it turns from a Hulke political parable into a typical runaround. Rather like watching socially aware paint dry.
